review_title: Great if you're a Japanese expatriate, average if you're a local
pros: 401k matching, Health, optional basic Vision & Dental, good perks especially at end of year, great camaraderie with locals, discounted Sony products, fairly stable.
cons: There are basically two worker strata: Japanese expatriates with 10x the benefits, their own HR department and zero motivation to go back to Japan, so it's usual to see senior figures hanging around in different assignments for up to 10 years, if they have friends in high places. The other stratum is comprised of locals, subject to a different set of rules and USA HR practices. Certain professional opportunities are limited to Japanese expatriates too, so you may find that you've reached your department/division ceiling, and the only option might be to move laterally. You might get lucky and score a good Japanese boss who'll empower and encourage you, but if you're not in one of the key and profitable consumer electronic or video game categories, you're likely out of luck, working harder, with much lower resources and struggling to keep up with demands and pressure from Tokyo HQ.
advice_to_mgmt: Make expatriate assignments no longer than 3 years with very few exceptions. Base a portion of expatriates' performance assessments on a timely and successful transition process with their successors, so one doesn't leave a position without even meeting (or barely so) the next-in-line and his/her staff.

cons: No cons, great company to work for.

review_title: Solid place to work but struggling to compete

pros: Good Benefits and office friendly

review_title: Once a leading brand, now in need of a reboot
pros: There was always challenging work always available. The opportunity to contribute to business in a meaningful way existed at many levels. Brand strength and affinity with consumers.
cons: Limited autonomy in some cases and decision making usually involved many layers, meaning that it was difficult to move quickly in response to the industry and environmental changes. Loss of local talent in recent years.
advice_to_mgmt: Delegation to the local team is critical to motivating employees. With the continued restructuring in the past several years, it was difficult to keep talented employees engaged and focused on thinking about the business. You will continue to lose talent unless there is an end to the annual cycle.

pros: Great place to work. work life balance.
cons: Delayed promotions for Indians in singapore. no responsibility.
advice_to_mgmt: need more assessment on work. Japanese are good at management and on hardware. Effective use of software and faster decision making will improve the profitability. reduce excess staff and should increase the responsibility.

pros: Powerful but diminishing brand. Smart people. Great international resources. Powerhouse PlayStation brand.
cons: PlayStation has abandoned the Sony name. Every commercial says PlayStation only - no mention of Sony. They previously did this on their former Vaio computer line using a sub-brand as a brand. They struggle for relevance and put the Sony name on products that they shouldn't.
advice_to_mgmt: If you remember what Steve Jobs did at Apple with the four quadrants. He had the entry level iMac, high end Mac, entry level MacBook and high end MacBook. That was it. Four products and he started the process for Apple to claw back. What does Sony want to sell in five years time? Figure that out and eliminate all the rest.

pros: Great work environment and work/life balance. Still have a good brand competiveness in the electronics markets. Good products and good RD.
cons: Top Management only from Japan, sometimes not understanding local markets. Too many changes in Top management, as Japanese mangares will relocate almost every 4 years, thus not having enough time to understand markets and trends.
advice_to_mgmt: Sony should let local offices have their own local Top Managers and Directors, not only to have a correct understanding form local markets but also to motivante its employees.

Too slow in making critical decisions. Not much direction given to the non-Japanese management. Massive layoff damaged the company culture severely.

review_title: It is a good company unfortunately it is on a downhill
pros: It is an Americanized Japanese company. Business travels to Asia.

pros: A very solid company structure that encourages input from all the levels. You feel like you can actually make a difference in the company as a whole no matter what position you hold.

pros: Terrific people, good products, and great work/life balance

pros: Great colleagues, easy to get in front of new customers due to company brand recognition

pros: Great work place. It was refreshing to work with Engineers from different Countries and backgrounds. Sony was also a great place to get training on products you work with.
cons: Too many tiers of Management. When this happens, the communication gap widens due to the egos that get involved. Engineers are creative people that don't want the hassle of having too many Chef's in the Kitchen.
advice_to_mgmt: Downsize your Management teams so your products get a fair shot. Don't get so caught up over so many titles because it gets in the way of productivity.

pros: Fun environment, always evolving, get to help people
cons: Store closed, delay, not enough money was put towards keeping the store...
advice_to_mgmt: Should've spoken out more often, there was a lot of potential growth in Sony and i get sad to watch it all crumble.

pros:
1) Some fantastic people who care and want to do a great job.
2) Competitive salaries (more than competitive at the director on up levels), good benefits
3) Most roles have a good work-life balance
cons:
1) The culture is not very good. Lots of layoffs, constant fear of losing your job. People protect their jobs, and don't worry about the company or the organization outside of their direct team
2) Things are often dictated at the micro level on high from company HQ
3) Most roles are just about executing plans from above. Innovation is often talked about, but innovative ideas are quickly squashed.
advice_to_mgmt: The culture of Sony has lost its way. There can often be a clash in cultures between East and West. The focus is not on innovation and delighting the customer. Too much ego, too much time wasted.

pros: Great benefits, great people, great facility with perks, employee events, etc.
cons: Lots of tenured employees. Low morale employees that stick around and are just there to "collect a paycheck".
advice_to_mgmt: Invest in your entry level/mid level employees for growth and development. Be open to taking risks and change the mindset of "this is how we have always done it."

pros: Some great people, with potential for providing strong contribution. History of strong technology; still some important patents. Decent pay and good benefits. Potential for important synergies between Sony pictures, Sony music, Playstation, Consumer electronics and professional electronics -- no competitors have that.
cons: Weak management with frequent turnover. No accountability. Constant re-shuffling of leadership in Japan means nobody has the incentive to take business risks and "own" important new initiatives. US management has been reduced to beancounters and apologists. True product management, strategic planning and R&D have all been decimated.
advice_to_mgmt: Take a page out of your competitor's playbook -- like Apple, Samsung, Nest, Sonos; hire innovative engineers and product planners in Silicon Valley to leverage latest trends. Commit to a new business initiative (like medical, networked home or digital cinema) and hire expert leaders to build the best team.

pros: Beautiful bldg, Recognizable brand, Gym, Exceptional Coworkers

advice_to_mgmt: Give regions more autonomy

As Sony in US is a satellite to the main decision making, there is little decision making locally. The main management team will not trust the drive and local talent to act autonomously.

advice_to_mgmt:
To Japan Management.( Locally is just a title.)Part of this reasoning above is there is a slight mistrust of the actions locally, which could be a cultural difference and maybe a local misunderstanding as well of business directions.
Lastly I think as advice to Sony is that despite having worked on your English communication skills (excellent to a greater extent,) it would be fair to say that there is ...still.. a Western Cultural misalignment, I can't see any change to this.

pros: Working at the previous Sony Style store was a good job for college students because of the flexible retail hours. Great coworkers and some great managers.

Pay is stupid low. Like many electronic stores, commission is where you make your money. But if you aren't that great of a salesperson but more of operations.. as in getting the store ready with visual tasks, keeping price tags up to date, etc.. you are still below the totem pole. If you are a salesperson who sells like a snake and make your numbers even though your process is unethical (giving random discounts for no reason, promises of extra items, free trade in even past the return policy), you'll receive a larger pay raise than someone who actually runs the stores operations.

Also.. no room for advancement outside the Sony retail division unless you brown nose your way to corporate management.

cons: Due to the layoffs and the way that they sacked the previous CEO, the majority of the employees have lost faith in the current CEO who has been in the company forever. He just doesn't have the charisma that the previous CEO had and he is basically HQ's puppet. Japan HQ is trying to control the US operations and more Japanese expats will take over management roles thus impeding local employees to get promoted. And unfortunately, Japan HQ is still struggling trying to figure out their own direction and strategy. Although the company is doing better, Sony overall is hurting and wouldn't be surprised if there are more layoffs. The HR department is also very weak and unfortunately don't really care about employees but more about the company.

review_title: Former Digital Imaging Specialist saddened that the CEO killed off the Sony Outlets
pros: Great employee benefits, discount, and an opportunity to see products as they came out.
cons:
The store manager. The lack of self control and anger management issues is what precipitated a near 100% turnover rate in employees. He was eventually fired, but only shortly before Sony closed all of its outlets.

The pay. I earned the company over $500,000.00 in a given year, but Sony couldn't justify a raise beyond 2%. Considering I produced a minimum 40:1 return on investment as an employee (could be as high as 60:1 if I went back and checked my pay stub), they could have tripled my pay and still had a substantial return.
advice_to_mgmt: Re-open your outlets. You shot yourself in the foot when you closed stores that were near international destinations. You had plenty of hard working employees, and there is no doubt that many of your stores made you money. The decision to gut this part of your business makes about as much sense as cutting taxes to reduce deficit spending.

review_title: Some stellar products, but a nightmare of a management structure.
pros:
- Amazing products, particularly in the Digital Imaging/Camera division.
- Employee Discounts
cons:
Where to start?

First off, I started as a seasonal. The way management treats its seasonal hires was what turned me off from the beginning. The amount of turnover this store experiences is unbelievable. If you're a seasonal, be prepared to have your sales stolen from the established sales people. Management turns a blind eye to this. Favoritism runs rampant; I saw them give a $700+ prize that was meant to be for the top salesman of the holiday season to a favorite, established employee who came in 2nd in sales that quarter. The top salesman was a seasonal that was let go because management didn't like him. I saw this man give all of his effort to making the store profitable, becoming top salesman, just to be stiffed on a prize he deserved more than anyone in that store. This was disgusting and unethical.

This alone would be tolerable if one didn't have to deal with the management structure; Five managers in a store with only eight sales people. The amount of cognitive dissonance I experienced on a day-to-day basis was insane; Managers would often order employees to do things that would contradict what another manager said to do, and they would get borderline passive-aggressive when you hesitated to do something they directed because another manager told you to do something different. Management in this store has some serious communication, and ego-trip issues. I have never felt so disposable, unvalued and unappreciated. I would miss my breaks, because managers would tell me to wait untill they told me it was okay to go, then they would forget. I would remind them and they would become visibly annoyed, "you should have told me earlier, now I have no coverage!" "didnt you just take a lunch?" Everyday was a constant battle to not just drop everything, quit and walk out of the store. I was coached multiple times a day for such petty, arbitrary reasons. It was exhausting. I'm a hard worker that gave 110% every time I stepped into the store, and yet, management made it very difficult to do my job and make the company money. I could give more examples, but I think you get the picture.

Commission is laughable. Almost not worth the effort. Your hours are cut if you don't sell enough, then you don't sell enough because your hours have been cut. It can become a downward cycle.

Dont get me wrong, I was extremely fortunate to have a job during my finally year in university. I survived two job cuts where 75% of the store's workforce was let go. The head manager is an amazing, friendly and understanding. I owe my job to him. This does not, however, excuse how poor is subordinate managers treated me and the other seasonals.
advice_to_mgmt: Leadership has some serious communication and ego issues. I think you should address the serious turnover you guys experience and work on making employees feel more valued. Good Luck!

review_title: A good notch for your resume if you can survive a 'House of Cards' environment
pros:
High company recognition - you'll never have to explain what Sony is.

An excellent primer for junior staff and new college grads - due to Sony's fast-paced work environment, you'll be exposed to a lot of business problems and scenarios that will be invaluable later in your career.
cons:
Organization Hierarchy - even in it's now leaner levels, Sony is a haven for middle+ management. The company is so awash in Mangers/Senior Managers/Directors/VPs/SVPs/EVPs that it's actually amazing there are people in the organization actually there for the day-to-day execution of actual "work." This places even greater stress on those individuals because that smaller section of talent is asked to perform at levels that support the bloated organization.

(Obviously Sony is downsizing, so if you're planning on applying, be sure to ask what the manager : individual contributor ratios are in the DIVISION your applying for.)

Work/Life balance - perhaps one of the worst in places I've worked at. Particularly for technical/engineering jobs - you'll work similar hours to a lean startup... just without the compensation that generally comes with those kinds of environments. This place WILL grind you - and as Sony downsizes this will only get worse, as now the same amount of work to sell, support, and engineer products is delegated to less and less people.

Office politics - cronyism at levels that would rival Government. The intensity of this was directly (inversely) proportional to the health of company. As numbers went down, and layoffs became more common, the environment grew commensurately toxic as working groups and division fought tooth and nail to prevent their silo from being placed on the chopping block. Also, other observations about "relationships with Japan," are accurate - knowing and having strong relationships with people in Tokyo is one of the best ways to ensure job tenure. It's also worth noting that over time, these kinds of environments change both your colleagues and yourself.

Lack of transparency - A lot of the discussions/decisions that many of us would have felt empowered knowing about were kept on a "need-to-know" basis - where that "knowing" imparted special status among higher management. Of course there are the "town halls" - but these very often we're cheer-leading sessions, particularly for products that we're less than stellar. Often felt more like being at a TupperWare party or AmWay conference than a legitimate forum for state of the business.

Low-ball compensation - As a hiring manager, this was a constant struggle in trying to work with HR to get pay ranges for positions in the San Diego location to *at least* at market levels, often times requiring special arrangements to make that happen. This made retaining talent difficult as companies like Qualcomm, Motorola (now Google) and other Engineering shops could offer better packages.

- Raises are paltry, particularly for Tech/Engineering
- Best benefits were reserved for Directors and Up

One NOTABLE exception was the 401K plan - which up until 2012 had a much higher matching contribution rate than market - with a caveat: 2yr vestment before matching contributions kick in.

Not a great place for non-JP engineers - you'll work on some fun projects, but chances are they'll be scrapped, as Sony doesnt have a good track record of supporting products they released that weren't breakout-successes (Aibo, Rolly, Dash, etc.. ).

Company Culture = Culture of your direct Manager - if you had a good Director or VP, then you could potentially be in a very positive environment, otherwise it was merely something in an e-mail that didn't reflect the reality of what you were directly incentivized by from your direct manager.

Lots of outsourcing - even for domestic operations. This essentially created two classes of Sony employees - the "Blue-Badgers (Full-time)" and "Red Badgers (Contractors)" - and the levels of ownership and collaboration were really almost on a vendor-by-vendor basis. Even more troubling was when vendors had to work with other vendors on Sony projects, as this created weird "tribal knowledge" dynamics in an effort to shunt more billable hours to their respective companies. This placed the Sony employees in difficult scenarios, and often Sr. Managers and Directors inherited messes directly created by these dynamics.
advice_to_mgmt:
Frankly; *go away* - it was incredibly clear that except for a couple of products and operational areas, all objectively quantifiable benchmarks have clearly demonstrated that the Electronics arm of Sony has failed both domestically (US) and Internationally.

Most of middle-management can be gone - and I would the argue same for much of the upper-management as well.

pros: Salaries are generally good, 401K is excellent - 100% match for first 3% and 50% on the next 3% of employee contributions, profit sharing, flexible work timings, generally stable employment, Sony historically has not been a company that lays off people at the drop of a hat, in a manner of speaking, although that has been changing in recent times.
cons:
Work is remote controlled from Tokyo, little to no autonomy for the US operation, so decisions take a long time to be made. Sometimes there is not enough transparency as to who is in control, and who is the real decision maker. Work efficiency sometimes suffers due to too many people involved in decision making, and the afore-mentioned lack of transparency of decision making.
       Staying back in office for late night video/telephone conference meetings with Tokyo teams had been the norm rather than the exception, due to the time zone difference.
       Lately the medical benefits, bonuses and profit sharing have been poor, whereas in Sony's heyday they had been truly spectacular.

review_title: It's like a merry-go-round. Somewhat pleasant, but in the end you have to decide when you want to get off.
pros:
Valuable experience good and bad, you can learn from.
Generally nice, friendly, respectful, professional people.
Great opportunity to be around so many people and backgrounds.
Talk often about being innovative. (Just don't ever really do it).
Talk about risk. (But end up doing something completely safe or for the wrong reasons).
Value presentation and premium aesthetic quality.
Still very nice quality in some of their products but do not always justify the price point.
Always trying to come up with new features. (But usually hardware based).
Great at about trying to decipher a diversified target audience with different shopper preferences.
New president provided some energy to some difficult times. And in fairness, a lot of natural disasters did happen to the company.
Talk about trying to improve things.
Nice looking, fairly impressive building.
Upper management generally very cordial and affable to lower management and employees.
Very nice when you walk in the door. Make you feel at home. Do their best not to be stuffy.
Decent benefits plan. (Sadly some people abuse the system).
cons:
Really have a difficult time separating strategy from approach.
Stopped being an innovation company and became a me-too electronics company.
Old OEM mindsets.
No clearly communicated or substantiated vision.
No common deductive approach. Look for holy grails and magic turn-keys.
No hard planning more than a few months at a time. (Largely overseas fault).
Too many missed opportunities and too late to market.
Poor cooperation between the other Sony entities.
Lots of redundancy between positions and at the same time, often too little support.
Trickle down marketing as opposed integrated marketing.
Lots of platitudes when it comes to business culture and objectives.
Useless line extensions with no clear point of difference.
Bureaucracy at home and overseas.
Lot's of finger pointing at home and overseas.
Focus on the wrong things sometimes and almost completely pedantical.
Can't seem to provide complete experiences like is competition.
Siloed business units.
Old perceptions of BTL and ATL.
Too many project managers, more like traffickers.
Often, unfair wage compensation, not based on ability or hours of work.
Often pretentious attitude that it is “a privilege” to work for or with Sony.
Constant layoffs and restructuring, not always justified to the right people and BUs.
No accountability but quick to place blame.
Sway their own research to fit the company mantra.
Horrible at refinement. Like to start over completely at scratch or bring back ideas that never work at all the first time. “Six steps forward, five and one-half steps back.”
Certain VPs and groups hold all the power.
Use “self-empowerment” as an excuse not to provide employees the right tools.
Lots of politics.
Sad they had to import leadership and they could not find it in the U.S.
Unethical human resource practices whereby employees were forced to take vacation at certain times.
Questionable ROI metrics.
Award ceremonies that seem to focus only on a few BUs.
Ambiguous responsibility matrixes.
advice_to_mgmt: Layoffs and restructuring with ridiculous new naming conventions are not the way to fix serious managerial and development problems.

pros: Great learning opportunities, flexible work culture
cons: Lack of processes and favoritism. No defined career path.

pros: Globally recognized. Once a true innovator of ground-breaking technology.
cons:
There is NO strategic direction or vision offered by senior management.
It's all about office politics.
Creativity, new ideas and hard work won't necessarily get you ahead and sometimes can hurt as those attributes are threatening to management's "business as usual" culture.
Too many layers of management. Too many senior level management. Not enough employees in the trenches to actually get the work done.
advice_to_mgmt: For the sake of the company you need to clean house at the top and bring in some fresh new blood with real leadership ability to reenergize and spark some true innovation - what this brand was founded on.

review_title: Prolonged misery punctuated by bouts of irrational hope
pros: Depending on your business unit and position, you may have the opportunity to travel to Tokyo HQ, conferences, etc. The pay is good, but below average for corporations of similar stature and certainly not worth the insane overtime. Despite hard times, Sony is still a prestigious name to work for, and projects can be interesting.
cons: Expect to work like a dog. Any mention of work/life balance is lip service and nothing more. As in many large organizations, there is little oversight and accountability, so if you are of the persuasion, you can get away with murder. If you aren't, expect those that are to keep you working 24/7 to carry their dead weight. Corporate culture is staid, conservative and as you can probably surmise, acridly bitter. If you aren't Japanese, you can forget the notion that you will ever be promoted. There are very few western "lifers" in the company, and those with a long term investment here are meandering due to low motivation. Project work is highly interesting and challenging, but anything worthwhile is suffocated by the culture of committees, meetings and paralyzing indecision or apathy.
advice_to_mgmt:
Money isn't everything. I got a 25% pay raise, a $5000 bonus and I'm still looking elsewhere. I work like a farm animal and haven't been promoted in years. I'm still doing the exact same job that I did when I first joined the company, even though I've demonstrated a strong ability to go above and beyond to do the work of a senior level employee in addition to my current workload.

Fight the Tokyo rigamarole with every fiber of your being, it will slow your progress, kill employee morale and blight your brand in the US. Cultivate a sense of community and pride, and make accountability a priority.

pros: Worked on some of the greatest products when they launched. Met some really great people along the way, that I am still in contact with -both professionally and personally.
cons: Not very promising for female career path if you are looking for growth and leadership potential. Sr. management is detached from day to day, and spend a lot of time managing approval from Japan. Go to market strategy is slow; despite all attempts at creating acronyms for speed. Overall vision is blurred as it is done by committee, and the committee is looking in the rear view mirror.

pros: Core of San Diego, best in electronics
cons: team i worked in was great, but there was some challenges above
advice_to_mgmt: none

pros: Well known conpany and good products
cons: Poor management and no creative products anymore.

review_title: They can be a great career
pros: Horizontal. They let you contribute and grow. Ideas were appreciated. Work was rewarding.
cons: They are floundering in the market at present.
advice_to_mgmt: Hire back some of the people you retired in 2009. Many are your competitors and they are eating your lunch.

pros:
Great employees who are all very friendly and have some great product knowledge. Everyone works with everyone employee wise to pick up shifts or trade them so if you need a day off you can always rely on someone.
Everyone employee wise is real close knit they will help you reach your sales goals.
cons:
Shady management staff who tries to get rid of people they don't personally like.
Terrible Hr staff, personally the worst i've dealt with. Josette never listens to the employees side of the story and goes straight for the managements side even when they're in the wrong.
Management and employees live by two separate sets of rules, management can be late as they want to be with no consequences and the employee staff even if they call in or have an emergency get written up.
Managers do not lead by example creating a very stressful environment.
advice_to_mgmt:
Stop bringing personal matters into the workplace.
Get a new Hr person.
Stop covering for each other while the employees look on the situations powerless to do anything.

pros: The brand has a great legacy
cons:
They can't get out of their own way. The organization is EXTREMELY silo'd. They spend so much time fighting each other for position they have nothing left for the marketplace.
When I started at the company 5 years ago all I heard was "We don't need to do all of those things everyone else is doing, were Sony" By year 4 I had had my fill of what SONY really stands for, SOON ONLY NOT YET. it's a shame but this brand is marching towards the end.

pros: Flexible work environment, good job options, good 401k, pension value plan, medical, dental and vision benefits, overall not that bad

advice_to_mgmt: Just listen to the customers & associates suggestions and make solid products.

review_title: It's an OK company to work

cons: no future for your career.

review_title: Pure technology company that strives to provide great customer service
pros: We have a robust customer service and support infrastructure and work hard to find innovative ways to reach our customers. It's more like a family here than many companies, and people do care. We also have opportunities to innovate which is fun and rewarding.
cons: There was a disconnect from working at a satellite office. Integrating more communication would help. Also, the company's financial difficulties and layoffs make for a stressful work environment.
advice_to_mgmt: Make smart product decisions, increase communication between departments and don't forget the satellite offices.

review_title: Sony is no longer a great employer
pros: Great benefits, good people to work with. A long history of engineering and product excellence. World top five brand leader.
cons: The company is doing drastic cost cutting to stay afloat, and is not able to pursue innovative new products because of financial issues.
advice_to_mgmt: Focus on new products and innovation, not selling assets - getting rid of your best people will lead to implosion even faster.

pros: Some really cool technology and lots of untapped potential. Most co-workers are very passionate and capable, if not shell-shocked from round after round of layoffs. A good place if you're really into office politics.
cons: Few, if any, of the executives are true leaders. The current path seems to indicate the company will become irrelevant -- there appears to be no real strategy whatsoever other than laying off more and more people. Colleagues in Japan are in no way aligned with local realities; duplicate and contrary efforts abound.
advice_to_mgmt: Try to explain why it's not hopeless, but don't sugarcoat the truth -- you do yourselves a disservice.

review_title: Sony is a great company to work for but mgmt is still stuck in the past
pros: Great incentives/gifts/trips... no micro-managing & flexible work life... it's always fun to sell consumer electronics instead of a widget
cons: Lack of recognition that competition is tough... pricing is higher than industry average... flat panel tv's are considered a commodity product by general public so high-quality differentiation is difficult
advice_to_mgmt: Let the past be the past and recognize that Samsung/LG have changed the landscape of the consumer electronics industry.

pros:
Flexible work hours, job autonomy. Good pay, nice work environment, building and amenities.
Smart people for the most part.
Good benefits, but not on par with "Best Places to Work" companies
cons:
Sad to see old culture driving this company into the ground.
No incentives or reward to do better.
Company asks you to commit but they are not reciprocal
I don't have the confidence that Sony will be around in 8 or 10 years.
advice_to_mgmt:
You can't just talk about being innovative, you have to advocate it.
Slashing research and headcount is only a temporary fix.

review_title: Great people, but the company is loosing too much money
pros: Top tier Benefits. Flexible work arrangements. Great facilities for those in the new building.
cons: Lack of Direction or constantly changing direction. Bonus tied to company profits, but there are not any profits. Everyone is working at least 6 days a week and 10+ hr days with no end in site.
advice_to_mgmt: Connect with the front line managers, focus on the customer, set a clear direction, and don't back down.

pros: I have worked in engineering, marketing, sales, & business management with several Sony companies
cons: We work for the benefit of the Japanese manufacturing employees, not the shareholders
advice_to_mgmt: Broaden the team making executive decisions to include middle management who actually works with customers

review_title: Surprised a Japanese company is so organizationally challenged.
pros: Great access to very cool products. Product discount program is very good. It's great to be associated with such a respected brand. Nice office environment. No set number of vacation days, you take them as you need/want with your manager's approval.
cons: Everything is an emergency; several fire drills per day. Management does very little planning and as a result we are always in catch-up mode. HR is invisible... we barely have any sort of performance review process, and almost no succession planning. Don't expect to be trained here. You learn as you go. Some groups work very long and stressful hours. Other groups barely put in 40 hours/week.
advice_to_mgmt: The marketing organization acts like a mafia and is mostly ineffective. It needs a management overhaul.

pros: Good environment. Good people. Good skills.

advice_to_mgmt: More diligence.

pros: Benifits are insanely so insane

advice_to_mgmt: Be nice to the peeons

review_title: Challenged with lots of competition but still an awesome brand!

advice_to_mgmt: Lets be aggressive but realistic... people still love us!

review_title: Losing innovation, old style politics, favoritism.
pros:
-Modern clean building in San Diego (Building 1).
-Able to learn new skills and tools (if you continuously ask), collaborate with people worldwide.
cons:
-Cutthroat management, instead of finding solutions to the problem. Middle management can be hostile towards the people doing the brunt of the work.
-Politics that require so many 'meetings' with ideas and products eventually getting cut.
-Favoritism, cronyism rampant.
-It appears that a large portion of the software side of the company are contractors and not full time employees. Why not just pay your employees the benefits and hire them?
-A feeling that your job can be potentially outsourced at anytime in Japan or China.
advice_to_mgmt:
Have the departments collaborate together rather then blaming the finger or outright firing for little reason.
Stop with the propriety formats in all your products.

pros: There is nothing I can say... Maybe just for store discount
cons: Favorite people get promoted... Nobody cares about skills, experience etc.,

review_title: It's not for everyone, but if you can maneuver through the politics, you can do really well.
pros: Discounts on lots of different products throughout the year. Great people to work with, too. Sony does try to do a lot for its people.
cons: A lot of old upper management with 20+ years call the shots so the thinking is very stagnant and it's all about keeping the same good ol' boys employed although they have no new ideas or bring much value to the table.
advice_to_mgmt: Evolve! Shake things up and bring in some new blood. You need to catch up with the times and start catering to those trying to fill a need but who don't necessarily want to break the bank to do it.

pros: Events, product discounts, great people who are all smart, on campus lunch good and cheap
cons: Not enough work, Segmented departments that should overlay, no space for design, ideas a killed in japan without much feedback.
advice_to_mgmt: FIght for american ingenuity.. We are the consumers why cant we help control the products.

pros: Co-workers are friendly and many friendships were made during my tenure there. Everyone wants to succeed and everyone works together to get projects done.
cons: Constant fear of job layoff can be a difficult work environment. Many times employees who are left after a layoff in a department are expected to continue performing or increase productivity with less manpower.

review_title: Review for Sony US Research Center, San Jose
pros: Benefits are decent. The building is conveniently located next to the San Jose airport.
cons:
Rank/file employee turnover at this business unit is incredibly high. Specifically, turnover is at least 4-5 times higher than most Silicon Valley companies. As a result, this business unit is "always hiring." In contrast, no one in senior management has left this business unit in the past 10 years.

HR is aware of some (but probably not all) of the problems that exist in this business unit. However, unlike an American company, HR is powerless to do anything.
advice_to_mgmt: Phil Molyneaux: You are in charge or US operations. Why is the employee turnover at this business unit so high? What are the complaints from former Sony Alumni, regarding this business unit? (There are a lot of US Research Center alumni out there.) Please find out. The best course of action is to disband the business unit, and to form a new one, with a brand new senior management team.

review_title: Very Nice place to work at, if..............
pros: Very nice strong engineers group, interesting projects.
cons: there are some cons when unhealthy balance of ............... tipping

pros: They provided me with an opportunity to make a difference. I provided information solutions where none existed before. I managed quality departments, reducing labor costs and improving product quality.
cons: Sony could not compete by manufacturing products in San Diego. They closed the VAIO computer factory in San Diego, and are producing all computers overseas now.
advice_to_mgmt: You need to find a way to leverage the talented work force that you have in order to be competitive in the world market.

review_title: Was a great company but is on the decline.
pros: Excellent opportunity to grow your career upward but also horizontally. The new HQ building is magnificent including an excellent health club. Very nice, dedicated employees.
cons: Their profitability is struggling. Future doesn't look good. They used to be cutting edge as far as bringing products to market but are not handling competition from Apple and Samsung very well. So much of the talent leaves Sony to join the competition.
advice_to_mgmt: Pay employees better, motivate them to stay at Sony rather than losing them to the competition. Cut overhead in Tokyo.

review_title: It was a pleasant experience, however changes
pros: Great time and experience working as an sales specialist. Sony offer some of the best product training programs that any company can offer to its employees. Great benefits such as 401k, tuition reimbursement, medical, vacation. It was very fun working there until the last few months before I left.
cons: Big changes in management which resulted bad, decaying work environment, and lack of communication are some of the problems. Benefits began to be reduced and career opportunities are not as common as before.
advice_to_mgmt: Please, as you understand the value of customers, please also understand the value of your employees, they are the backbone of the company and good leadership will help Sony achieve to the top of success.

review_title: Very satisfied with work culture, good to employees

review_title: This company is not managed properly

advice_to_mgmt: It is too late to recover from all the bad decisions made in the last decade.

pros: so much new technologies to work on and great team work in oversee

advice_to_mgmt: Better benefits.

review_title: A great company to gain experience in the corporate world, but at times draining
pros: Stability, multiple employees allow for great networking, lots of variety in business units-allows for exposure to different opportunities
cons: Poor, inconsistent decision making; employees are often taken for granted, no acknowledgement for achievements, often a frustrating atmosphere to push projects through
advice_to_mgmt: Improved decision making, consider company money as if it were your own, allow suitable time for projects to be developed (deadlines are overemphasized for unexplained reasons).

pros:
Great work environment
Very cool products
Very nice people willing to provide assistance whenever asked.
Excellent work-life balance
cons:
Sony no longer a household name.
Pursued "content" strategy rather than a "manufacturing" strategy which caused smaller Korean and Chinese competitors to gain market share and ultimately pass them.
No career path.
advice_to_mgmt: Need a new strategy and vision for this company.

review_title: Consumer and Market Analysis utilizing all inputs of voice of the consumer like secondary research, proprietary and buzz
pros: Flexibility. Brand power. People. Location.
cons: Large organization pitfalls, slow to react sometimes.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep being transparent, even take it up a notch; especially around things that directly affect employees like benefits changes.

pros: no micromanagement. quiet and respectful place to work. the sony brand is strong and respected, although it has suffered a little in the recent past.
cons: Decisions are not made quickly, US has to always check each detail with Japan which takes time. Decisions are not made until everyone is pleased...group think. Hardware team always nickels and dimes the HW platform, leaving software developers to have to deal with low performance HW. Projects are commonly done jointly with Japan, which adds to the sluggishness, due to distance and language barrier.
advice_to_mgmt: break the company into Japan and US branches. each local region can make autonomous decisions. each region creates products to the common sony spec. minimize the number of models/products.

pros: Sony offers a wide variety of solutions in the consumer electronics realm. They have an on-site gym and a great location to work in.
cons: The internal politics of the company are just astounding. Simple tasks become insurmountable, nearly herculean efforts. Everything is controlled out of Japan, and they simply ignore the cultural differences and assume you have some level of knowledge from their culture which makes their statements and policies understandable. I guess politeness is also a cultural aspect as I find some of the Japanese management people to be extremely inconsiderate and rude.
advice_to_mgmt:
Sony needs to change in order to survive. That is also the mandate from high up - however it stops solid in middle-management level. Great initiatives and ideas are stopped cold by old-time policies (this is how we do it and we won't change it now) and mixed messaging is being distributed to the workers (we're told to think different - to change - to break down the barriers of old, but still held to the same silos that brought this great company into the administrative and political mess it is today).

Take a close look at the middle management and track who actually enforces policies and embraces change - I think you will find some surprising results...

review_title: Good learning experience, but had to leave to realize how limited opportunities were
pros:
+ The brand is still relevant in certain categories
+ Manageable work-life balance
+ Employees are passionate about the company
cons:
+ Company is accelerating towards irrelevancy
+ Not enough "topgrading" of talent. A lot of tenured and mediocre "B" players stuck in middle management, limiting advancement opportunities
+ Decisions are slow and management is indecisive.
+ So frustrating to see nimbler competitors run circles around us
advice_to_mgmt: Stop focusing on cost and focus on the delivering a unique experience to the customer. Get out of the businesses where we can't do this. Clean house on your staffing -- remove the tenured top and middle management. Find way to attract and retain talent. Realize who you want to complete against for talent and compensate accordingly. You won't get Google talent paying what Sony pays. You won't get the results from the ones who take what you pay them!

pros: Good people with good benfits and good product.
cons: Loss of focus on customers
advice_to_mgmt: Don't lose sight of the fact that the end user is the most important thing

review_title: A lot of politics. It is who you know, not how you perform

Enough Planning in the last 5 years, and billions $ loss. WAKE UP, do the right thing and make the name SONY once more proud. Sony on the sliding slope since that Stringer showed up.

pros: Some good people and decent pay.

advice_to_mgmt: Let your workers know what;s going to happen and listen to there ideas.

review_title: It used to be a great place to work, until we got behind the competitors.

review_title: Daily Interactions from A to Z under the same roof, Equal EXCITEMENT.

pros: overall its a good place to work , people are professional , benefit are good , the management does care about its employees.

review_title: Good managers in a company that follows an old business model

Managers who stay out of the way of engineers
Fun people with whom to work
Interesting R&D projects

This company is on the downslide and seems to be stuck in a very old business model
When attempting to reshape it's future, the company has chosen weak projects that have no marketability and little chance of helping balance it's books
The company wants to compete on a scale with Amazon and Google but makes tragic strategic decisions and has no sense of tactics
While fun to work with the latest hardware toys out of Japan, these are mostly underpowered devices with weak marketability
This company has HUGE communication problems with Japan where the American subsidiary is supposed to come up with the new ideas to help the company going forward and the Japanese headquarters has a very long approval process for any American initiative that is not often approved because of the communications gaps and the cultural differences
advice_to_mgmt: If you're going to save the company, the American side has to start doing projects that are relevant, that build an ecosystem of connected products, and that are suited to facilitate the new world of FB, Google, Apple, and Amazon.

review_title: Great place to work but company structure needs to be changed
pros:

If someone you're working with steps on a banana peel outside the building it's your fault and you'll be in hot water. No one ever willing to take responsibility for their own work, or no one ever willing to make a decision and stand by it. Overlapping roles and responsibilities so no one knows what they're doing. A LOT of dumping of trying to get other people to do your work cuz, well I guess you don't feel like doing it so if you can dump that onto another department and make a stink, because roles and responsibilities are not defined almost as principle. They take pride in not having clearly defined roles and responsibilities.

One of the items on the performance review is how well you deal with ambiguity, unclarity, constantly changing priorities and constant changing of direction. Isn't this just asking how well you deal with "we are unorganized, don't know what we're doing, don't know what we should do, change our mind on a whim because some abusive person got mad or doesn't like something we did so to avoid getting in trouble we blame others or change direction quicker than the wind, we have no concept of what will be successful so we change it up 50 times to see what sticks, Oh no our competitor just did this we need to change ours" ?? Uh yeah -
advice_to_mgmt: Define roles and responsibilities so everyone has a clear idea of who does what and communicate that please. The hours you are required to work, coupled with the worst of corporate politics, high school like behavior and mentality just make a career here unsustainable. Case in point: SEL cannot hold onto its "best and brightest". The outstanding performers who make a difference continue to walk with no effort seemingly made to retain them. "The good ones never stay" has become a sad mantra for those who have watched the departures. Sony has become a very hollow place - it's all about image and window dressing and, like the shiny products, there is nothing meaty to back it up. Employees have very little distinction between personal and professional lives - it becomes one because all you do is work - and way, way below market rate. It's mind blowing to find out what former colleagues are making once they leave. Then there are the exhausting politics. You'll find politics anywhere in life but it is over the top at SEL. It's a full time job to keep up with the backstabbing and mind games. The worst part is you'll find people even at the VP and above level responsible for stirring the pot. If you let employees spend more time focused on the job at hand and less on politics, the company may stand a chance. There are very few to look to in the way of mentors or to even learn management skills from. Some higher ups have spent their entire lives working for only Sony and have coasted along with little skill and no ongoing development. They continue to enjoy the ride while the compnay sinks. Is anyone paying attention?? I plan to be one of the next to leave.
advice_to_mgmt: SEL has become a vain place run by ego. That's a rough but true statement. Please, please pay more attention to what is going on in the organization. Look at all the great people leaving, figure out why and fix it before the company crumbles. I for one had high hopes with the new president coming in but he already seems snowed by the company's worst offenders. Depressing.

review_title: Great people but needs better organization.
pros: Very knowledgeable coworkers. Interesting consumer projects like HDTVs. Also exciting being part of a huge corporation who makes waves at events like CES or in online publications like CNET. Work equipment is never in short supply if needed, so from an engineering standpoint they will provide you with what you need to get the job done. cons: Information sharing could be much better despite the utilization of some tools like Microsoft Sharepoint. Very little documentation, such as functional specifications, are created or updated for even the riskiest modules. For SQA, this is an exercise in frustration because what you think is a defect is actually a "new feature." And often you are asked to compromise on obvious bugs because the development team desperately wants to meet a closed-defect milestone. Also, at times development exerts too much influence on SQA activities. SQA should be a separate entity working WITH development towards a common goal, not working FOR development. Also hours can be RIDICULOUS often requiring 60-70 hour weeks, with no compensation, just a measly "thank you" from upper management. And did I mention they're charging for coffee and tea? Way to annoy your workers who work long hours with no overtime, Sony. Since we're on the topic of pay, Sony's average salary for Software QA is far below the San Diego average. I make less than the average SQA pay in San Diego.
advice_to_mgmt: Appreciate your employees. We work long hours for no compensation, and we deserve to be recognized. Words dont cut it. Also, projects often end in major panic attacks and demands from management for long hours and weekend work. But for what? Salary is below average in the area. Also, better organization is a must going forward. That includes creating relevant documentation for all new features, software diagrams to show how the module interacts in the overall system, and they should be UPDATED, not forgotten. Trying to find pertinent documentation requires countless number of clicks to navigate through their Sharepoint website. Documentation needs to be consolidated and it's location broadcasted across the company so there will be no questions where documentation should be located.

pros:
By far, most work there for the brand name "Sony". You can go to a store anywhere in the world, and see a product you worked on. If someone asks where you work, and you reply Sony, they know who you work for.

Another good reason to work at Sony is that the company is so wasteful that you are likely to pick up all sorts of castoffs as they are thrown out. This can be anything from a perfectly good remote control to a vehicle that they no longer want.
cons:
All groups are like independent companies. No one shares anything. By groups, i mean anything like an entire division like Vaio asking the flat panel TV group for a tool, and the TV group either saying "go buy your own" or "lets get your budget code!" Or, groups can be just 2 or 3 people within the same business unit. If those guys own something, and you need it, forget it. I have had to hire in temps just to get help in my group while other groups have useful human resources sitting chatting (in Japanense), or surfing the internet.

Also, I have worked there for many years, and never once has anyone offered to train me (or anyone else) on anything. No one gets trained for any job. At Sony job "training" is eithics, or company security. I have not received on piece of new information since I have worked there. However, the Japan side does receive a very fair amount of traing and mentorship.. In some case Sony will put an american employee with a Japanense member so the American can train them. This is very typical for someone that is hired with a special skill, that japan must have.

It's also taboo to talk directly to anyone higher up than your group manager. No one does, and we all know what will happen if you go over your manager's head to his boss. You will be eliminated.

Advancement happens to those that keep their mouth shut, do their work, and praise the decisions of their managers. One could stay there for years, just keeping their head down and agreeing with everything. Job loss comes quick to those who don't play along, try to make changes, or doubt the company. Stroking the egos of the Japanese engineers will take you far.

If you work as an engineer in San Diego, here's what to look forward to:

Your ideas will never be heard (they don't even want to hear your ideas!). Creative aspects of the job is all done in Japan.

Engineering in San Diego are nothing more than debuging and modification of Japan's mistakes.

The IT computer network is terrible, email is limited, and there's plenty of down time. We can't even share files with the plants in Mexico, or Japan. Any file must be emailed, or put on a CD and mailed to the recepient. Even though Sony makes computers, very few if any are ever replaced. My desk computer is a PIII built in 1996. Sony has not bought new software in at least 8 years. The office still uses WinXP, and Office 2003. New tools must be snuck in, and so many computers run pirate software just so we can get our jobs done. After Sony's IT staff get's your computer and sets it up on the network, the computer will run so slow that it's basically useless. I just bring my computer in from home, and use a sprint card to do real work (like CAD).

Tools are hard to come by at Sony. Another part of the silo problem. I can't even find a screw driver half of the time to take apart a TV. If you need something like a DVM, forget it, you'll never find one unless you have one bought for you, and hord it at your desk under lock and key. O'scopes are everywhere, but scope probes are nowhere, so we just don't use the O'scopes. Who knows how many issues are misseed because.

Expect a lot of "Cost Down Activity". It's just part of the job.

If you came in as say a "audio engineer", expect to one day to just be moved to some other job without them consulting you first. One day your the sound guy and the next, your working on tuners, and with no training. My job has changed on me about 4 times now. Sooner or later this is what will drive someone to quit.

Expect your desk to moved at least every 6 months, and your manager to be changed about every year.

Plan on working at least 10 hours a day, and when needed 12, or even 20. Weekends at Sony are typically work days for most engineers. No, you won't get paid for the overtime.

If you find a serious problem, be prepared to prove it with plenty of data. Almost as if you were going to court. If you don't the problem will stay or get solved by someone who had the time to prove it with "data" If a manager doesn't want to hear about your issue, expect to present even more data and reports to prove it. Even then, Management may know of the short coming and decide it's a business decision to ship the product with a known defect.

Also be prepared for lifers that are basically useless, to you, the company and the customer. They stay until they are offered early retirement. Some of these guys have worked for Sony for 30+ years.

Watch for the egos of the Japanese engineers. You will need to be humble to them.

Expect to work for years, and never get noticed or advanced.

Don't expect to be doing "design work" Design is not done in San Diego.

Oh, and no job is safe. A downturn, and Sony will fire entire divisions with little or no warnings when money is tight. There's no loyalty to US members.

Sony typically offers no stock options, pension, or carreer managment. They do offer 401k match, but the funds in it are not too good, even in good times.

If you're looking for a fun engineering job, in an open culture, with creativity, then keep looking. Sony Electronics is not for you.
advice_to_mgmt: Sony's brand means quality, but recent changes to reduce cost are going to ruin this reputation. Without that name, Sony is done. Recent products like PS3, Reader, Milo, Cybershot, Bravia, and Blu-Ray net walkman have serious issues, most related to software quality. Sony, you do not know software. The software is what makes the product. And Sony, you don't know how to manage talent. Great ideas have come and gone right under your nose. If you're only going to listen to Japanese designers, use asian made software, and continue to cheapen your product line, the Sony as you know it will be gone. Quality is more important than product cost! The products software is the quality. It's the software stupid!

cons:
Extreme politics between groups and corporations within the Sony umbrella. Non Japanese corporations and employees are treated as second class.

The standard project life cycle is the following:
1) Non Japanese group develops technology, iterating through releases until there is some success, either technical, or sales.
2) Japanese group identifies the successful project, transfers/consumes the knowledge, and responsibility.
3) Original development group is disbanded, or left to fend for itself on what ever new project it can muster.

pros:
It may be because Sony's corporate culture is Japanese, or that it is a global and diversified company but in my few years working there, I've never been seen layoffs or massive budget cuts. Yes, reorganizations have happened and departments were physically moved to other cities in the state but that's the extent of my observations. As such, if I wanted to Sony to be my last employer until I retire, there's a very good chance I could make it happen. And that's saying something for a Silicon Valley employer.

Sony Electronics makes a lot of products, a lot of gadgets and has R&D teams behind all of them. Surely, there's more than one that will benefit from your expertise. The diversity and quantity of the projects at Sony is another plus it's got for itself. And no matter what consumers may think down the line of our products, they still ship. Oh yeah, that's right, you'll be working on products that ship. That's another thing not every Silicon Valley business can say.
cons:
Working in a Japanese company in the U.S. will be seen by most as an opportunity at first. Well, after some time, it becomes a challenge. And after more time, it can be a downright hindrance to progress as you imagine it in your non-Japanese mind. My personal contact with Japanese business people is non-existent. That means I get no exposure to the cultural aspect of the business but all the exposure to its decisions that I often don't understand. That can be frustrating at times. Mind you, that's true for any foreign company that has opened shop in the U.S. But, let's just say that some foreign companies are more foreign than others.

Sony is not a software company. It's CEO recognizes that and wants it to change but, personally, I don't feel like waiting the 20 years for it to happen. For instance, there is no sense of community for people like me at the company level. As a software developer, I have countless online outlets available to me when I face some software related problem. But finding the other Sony employee who has the answer to your Sony-related question? That's unheard of.
advice_to_mgmt: Reconsider the reasons why you decided to have a base in Silicon Valley. If you think they still apply today, great. But we should be allowed to function like a SV business. One that can tap in the resources of a multinational company.

review_title: Great brand but this Japanese-style company facing increasing challenges across the board
pros: Great brand -- well-known, powerful, a career resume asset. If you love the category (consumer electronics) you will appreciate access to the latest and greatest technologies. International exposure (mostly with Tokyo and US-based Japanese colleagues) is a plus, especially if you plan on having an international management role later on. Linkages with Playstation and Sony Pictures are strong and getting stronger, so there are interesting opportunities that arise due to those relationships like getting to attend premieres, previews of new films, and the chance to do strategic partnerships. Breadth of business is incredible, so exposure to all sorts of media and technology business happen with great frequency.
cons: Not a great environment for an MBA-type. Very old school, and old boys club in terms of environment. "Post Office" type of organization where keeping your head down, developing relationships, and just being at the office will eventually move you up the ladder or at least create strong job security. Not a place for people who want to rise quickly and make change happen. This will probably chnage as company becomes more and more impacted by the rise of newcomers to industry (Smasung in TV, Apple in portable devices, etc) but the overall stratification of the organization will make rapid changes difficult to deploy. Also a very Japanese-centric work environment on a number of fronts -- employees often work 8-midnight in order to get the US business complete while waiting for Tokyo to "wake-up" and provide direction. Not a true marketing organization, but instead a "sales office" -- this means that many decisions need to have the input and/or arte made by the teams in Tokyo. Because of this the Sales Organization is the powerhouse of the company and has tremendous power, which makes marketing even less impactful.
advice_to_mgmt: This could be a great company but it seems divided into two camps: lifers who tend to have come in as very low level employees (this includes many of the senior management folks) and new blood who either decide to become lifers or who give up and leave. It's also a very nave;-gazing culture -- I have seen employees interviewed for marketing jobs who don't actually know what the 4 P's are simply because they are alredy employed at Sony. In the coming world of CE, the game is going to be ecided by talent, and the talent development/retention as well as hiring seems sub-par.

review_title: Do your research on this company...
pros: Benefits are second to none. When I started, I was given 3 weeks of vacation and insurance started day one. The starting salary is very good as well. Employees of Sony are well compensated in all areas and have potential to earn more based on performance.
cons: On of the many downsides was the lack of training that is given within the first 3 months I started. It was very sparse and much of it was "learn as you go" as management would shuffle you around to others before getting the answer to questions. There was also a severe lack of leadership on senior and direct supervisor management. Much of the time, the support that was given only when it benefited them and was absent when it did not. They distanced themselves from you when times were bad and took all the credit when times were good.
advice_to_mgmt: I would tell them now, that give all employees an equal chance. Train and nurture your employees within their first 90 days, follow up and do not jump to conclusions when something goes wrong. And most importantly, treat each person the same, not giving favor to those that you like better personally.

Of course, I'm only speaking from my perspective at my particular department, but there is this general feeling of boredom and lack of inspiration. The contract work situation is fairly strange, because there are so many people that don't really have a voice. This leads to culture drain, and may be a large contributor to the 'blah' factor.
advice_to_mgmt: Invest in developing relationships with your people. There is a lack of culture building activity going on at Sony. Other companies I've worked at have realized the importance of relationship building activities, and Sony really misses the mark here. Also, please explain why I should have to wear business clothes at a tech company. If you relax the dress code and add some arcade games or something, people would have more fun at work.
